head.title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Fires and Global Warming

hedline.hl1: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Fires and Global Warming

abstract.p: Scientists contend that Indonesian drought of 1997 led to draining of peat bogs creating increased wildfires and causing substantial rise in carbon dioxide emissions that year; peat is so dense and prolific that it can smolder for months and if draining continues environment can be significantly impacted (S)

block.p: Scientists say the draining of Indonesian peat bogs greatly worsened vast wildfires that swept the country during a record drought in 1997, and thus also contributed to a big rise that year in global emissions of carbon dioxide, the main heat-trapping gas linked to global warming. In a study in today's issue of the journal Nature, researchers concluded that fires in the peat, which can be 60 feet thick and smolder for months, are likely to add to climate change if drained areas continue to expand.
